author: By Mia Leimkuhler and Sofia Sokolove
title: Week 3 of Our August Grilling Challenge: Grill Beyond the Expected
description: Because you can’t subsist on hot dogs alone. Plus: a really great deal on Wirecutter’s favorite olive oil.
content: Hello there! Welcome back. Week one was all about fine-tuning those grilling basics; week two was all about throwing an excellent cookout. Now? We’re getting creative, because no one can subsist on grilled hot dogs alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: What I Want a University President to Say About Campus Protests
description: A community of learners is guided by the spirit of inquiry.
content: As college students return to campus, this is what I hope a university president might say to them about how their school intends to handle future protests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Mexico’s Judges Vote to Strike, Opposing Overhaul of Legal System
description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador wants judges elected, not appointed. Court workers have already walked out to protest his plan, which critics call a power grab.
content: Federal judges voted on Monday night to go on strike across Mexico, protesting President Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s proposed overhaul of the country’s judicial system. The judges will join thousands of other court employees who went on indefinite strike earlier in the day over the contentious policy changes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: Biden’s Lackluster Speech Is a Reminder That He Couldn’t Win
description: The country’s spirit has moved on.
content: President Biden’s speech on Monday night was a reminder of why the Democrats were right to make the switch to Kamala Harris as their candidate for president. I expected something personal from Biden, ruminating on his life, commitments and the hills and valleys of a long career. Instead, we got a familiar campaign speech that was about as personal and moving as a platform committee report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: What Happened to Inflation?
description: In the end, Bidenomics was vindicated.
content: Surging inflation during President Biden’s first two years took a huge toll on his popularity, and the memory of that inflationary episode is probably the main reason that, at least until recently, polls showed Donald Trump with a large advantage on the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Surrounding Glow
description: Sam Buchbinder shares a few of his favorite things.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Five Weeknight Chicken Recipes That I Cook Again and Again
description: Several are made in one pan, most should be eaten with rice and all are fantastic.
content: Hello! Mia here, filling in for Emily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Amagansett Was Their ‘Happy Place.’ Renovating Made It Happier.
description: Raising three children in Hoboken, N.J., they always looked forward to summer at the beach in New York. Now they have a home there that’s really their own.
content: As they raised three children in Hoboken, N.J., Joan and Kyle Enger faced all the usual stresses of busy family life, stretched between work and parenting. But one reassuring constant was the knowledge that each summer there would be time to kick back in Amagansett, N.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: 7 New Collaborations You Should Hear Now
description: Hear music from pairings that include Lady Gaga and Bruno Mars, and Post Malone and Chris Stapleton.
content: It’s time once again for your monthly digest of recommended new music, culled from the Friday Playlists that Jon Pareles and I compile each week. This month’s collection has a twist: It’s composed entirely of collaborations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Abend
title: ‘The Demand Is Unstoppable’: Can Barcelona Survive Mass Tourism?
description: This summer, thousands of local protesters in the Spanish city denounced overtourism. With more crowds expected for the America’s Cup, we visited the areas where tensions are highest.
content: On a steamy August evening, a stream of young people bearing boxes of pizza and bottles of cheap cava began the uphill slog to Carmel Bunkers in Barcelona. Set on a hill overlooking the Catalan capital, the concrete structures once housed antiaircraft weapons that protected the city during Spain’s civil war in the 1930s. Later the site became a destination for residents on evening strolls and a hangout for local youths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Greenpeace Tries a Novel Tactic in Lawsuit Over Dakota Access Pipeline
description: The environmental group, which is being sued by the pipeline company in North Dakota, threatened to use new European rules to try to limit potential damages.
content: Greenpeace recently unveiled a new strategy for fighting a costly lawsuit by an energy company that the group contends is designed to silence critics of the oil industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Fighting for Love and Survival as a Country Falls Apart
description: In his fast-paced novel, Alejandro Puyana recounts the struggles and impossible choices of a family in deeply troubled Venezuela.
content: A memorable scene in Alejandro Puyana’s debut novel, “Freedom Is a Feast,” involves three “white city boys” and a bag of blood. It’s the 1960s in the coastal jungles of Venezuela. These young men from Caracas have been taken in by the romance of revolution. And now, by the military that’s trying to crush it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nam Le
title: This Collection of Poems Is Skeptical About Poetry’s Value. Or Is It?
description: Danez Smith’s “Bluff” represents a notable turning point for the poet — and maybe for American poetry as a whole.
content: The intent seems clear from the very first words: “anti poetica.” This is the title of the opening poem in Danez Smith’s “Bluff,” and it’s a title that recurs twice more in the collection. Smith’s commanding litany draws us through a run of negatives — there is “no poem wiser than kindness”; “no poem free from money’s ruin”; “no poem in the winter nor in whiteness” — stopping at:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Disciplinary Charges Against Top New York Police Official Are Dismissed
description: An oversight board had recommended that Jeffrey Maddrey, the chief of department, be punished for interfering with an arrest. Commissioner Edward Caban dismissed the case.
content: Commissioner Edward Caban of the New York Police Department dismissed the disciplinary charges against a top chief who had interfered with the arrest of a retired officer who had chased three boys while armed, according to an internal document.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Tennessee Prison Is Under Federal Investigation After Reports of Abuse
description: State audits of the Trousdale Turner Correctional Center, outside Nashville, have suggested that understaffing and high turnover have created an unsafe environment.
content: The Justice Department said on Tuesday that it was investigating conditions at a troubled correctional facility outside Nashville over reports that understaffing and high turnover of employees have contributed to the physical and sexual abuse of prisoners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Three Women Testify to the Effects of State Abortion Bans
description: One of the women, who was impregnated by her stepfather as a child, recalled Donald J. Trump’s praise for the bans as a “beautiful thing” and asked, “What is so beautiful about a child having to carry her parent’s child?”
content: In the two years since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, women who have been denied abortions, often in tragic circumstances, have become powerful messengers for Democratic candidates up and down the ballot — giving interviews, filming ads and, now, appearing at the Democratic National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Ernesto Londoño, Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith
title: Activists Protest Outside Consulate of Israel While Democrats Meet in Chicago
description: The demonstration was among several protests during the convention so far. The police said they would not tolerate violence.
content: Dozens of pro-Palestinian protesters faced off with the Chicago police outside the city’s Israeli consulate on Tuesday night, about two miles from the arena where the Democratic National Convention was underway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: In Chicago, Obama Aims to Resurrect a Movement
description: Also, Biden approved a secret new nuclear strategy. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: This evening, Barack Obama will headline the second night of the Democratic convention in Chicago, the city where his political career began. Like 2016, when he championed Hillary Clinton, he will attempt to use his political star power to help fuel the ascension of the country’s first woman president, and warn voters of the perils of a Donald Trump presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Search Resumes for British Mogul and 5 Others After Yacht Sinks Off Sicily
description: The body of the vessel’s cook was recovered while divers searched the hull of the Bayesian for passengers, including the tech entrepreneur Mike Lynch.
content: Deep-sea divers with Italy’s firefighter corps resumed their search on Tuesday for six missing passengers — including a British software mogul and his daughter — of a yacht that sank off the coast of Sicily the previous day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Lisa Lerer
title: Beyond Restoring Roe: Democrats See Moment to ‘Reimagine’ Abortion Rights
description: The spotlight at the convention is a dramatic shift from just four years ago, another sign of how radically the politics of abortion have changed, and how much the party is relying on the issue to rally voters.
content: It was one of the opening night’s most dramatic and sober moments. Three women emerged on the main stage, each in a spotlight against the darkness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Lynsey Chutel
title: Kenyan Accused of Serial Killings Escapes From Police Custody
description: The police think that the suspected killer, Collins Jumaisi Khalusha, may have had help breaking out. A manhunt was underway.
content: The Kenyan authorities have launched a manhunt for a suspected serial killer who escaped from custody after being accused of killing scores of women, the national police said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Caitlin O'Keefe
title: The Democrats Throw Joe Biden a Goodbye Party
description: Night One of the D.N.C. saw an extended ovation for the president and a roster of star speakers.
content: Last night, thousands of people gathered in Chicago for the first night of the Democratic National Convention. And the crowd at the United Center was ready for a party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Soltis Anderson
title: What Polls Are Telling Us as Democrats Convene in Chicago
description: Trump better move fast to define Harris.
content: At the Democratic National Convention this week, Kamala Harris faces a challenge. She must understand and speak to voter concerns on major issues like the economy without being downbeat. She must highlight her experience as President Biden’s right-hand woman without aiding Republicans in their efforts to link her to voter frustrations with Mr. Biden’s presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy X. Wang
title: Who’s Afraid of the Big, Bad Tradwife?
description: Why women who dress up as 1950s homemakers are driving the internet insane.
content: I’ve got this dress. You would recognize it; you’ve seen it everywhere, gracing storefronts and magazines and banner ads. Perhaps you own a version, too. Serenely patterned in the spirit of a picnic, it has soft, floaty fabric; sometimes it’s pin-tucked with bell sleeves, other times fitted with a sweetheart neckline, waist-cinching cotton voile, crochet detailing. You might imagine wearing the dress while trundling through fields of waist-tall wildflowers, homemade biscuits and lovely fruits in a basket slung over your elbow, a Lassie look-alike nipping happily at your heels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison, Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman and Adam Rasgon
title: U.S. Push for Gaza Cease-Fire Falls Short on Key Points, Officials Say
description: Israeli and Hamas officials have downplayed the idea that a deal could be imminent, saying that mediators’ efforts have not resolved major disputes.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken pressed on Tuesday for a cease-fire in the Gaza Strip, but officials familiar with the latest U.S.-backed proposal said it left major disagreements between Hamas and Israel unresolved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: At the Ruhrtriennale, Searching for the Sublime Among the Ruins
description: In the abandoned industrial sites that serve as the festival’s venues, our critic witnessed beauty struggling to be born: fitfully, clumsily and sometimes stunningly.
content: “I Want Absolute Beauty,” the title of the opening production for this year’s Ruhrtriennale, sounds like a mission statement of sorts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Minyon Moore Helped Harris Rise. Now She’s Leading Her Convention.
description: The longtime Democratic operative’s role overseeing the convention has required her to step out from behind the scenes.
content: When Vice President Kamala Harris takes the convention stage to formally accept the Democratic nomination on Thursday, it will mark the culmination of decades of public and behind-the-scenes work to make the party more reflective of its multiracial base.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan and James Glanz
title: Why Amtrak’s System Keeps Breaking Down: It’s 100 Years Old
description: An explosion at a substation in June caused just one in a series of disruptions along the Northeast Corridor this summer. Upgrades would come at enormous cost and take more than a decade.
content: It was just before rush hour on a Thursday afternoon, and all of the trains between Philadelphia and New Haven, Conn., were at a standstill. But the alert Amtrak sent out did little to calm seething commuters: All it said was that service was suspended because of an “overhead power outage.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Crouch
title: Do You Really Need Dilation at Every Eye Exam?
description: Experts disagree on who needs it and when. Here’s what the evidence suggests.
content: Perhaps the most unpleasant part of an eye exam is when the doctor squeezes in the dreaded drops to dilate your pupils. They sting your eyes, blur your vision and leave you squinting at screens for hours. As you blink back tears, it’s natural to wonder: Is this really necessary?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ralph Jones
title: Why Is Custom Framing So Expensive? One Man Investigates.
description: Framers say they aren’t getting rich protecting some of your most precious memories and art, but they know you have sticker shock.
content: If you’ve ever walked into a professional framers, you’ll be familiar with a sense of confused outrage. At first glance, it isn’t clear why buying a small frame at Target should cost $9 and buying the same frame at a custom framers should cost as much as a Louis Vuitton handbag. The knee-jerk response is to assume that you are being ripped off.  You are one of the few people too smart to fall for that kind of scam. Corruption must lie at the heart of the framing profession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman and Graham Dickie
title: After 62 Years, Brooklyn Says Goodbye to a Local Hardware Store
description: To mourn the closure of Crest Hardware, a beloved family business in Williamsburg, fans of the store held a wake and staged a second line march.
content: “We are gathered here tonight,” the Rev. Vince Anderson began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Phil Donahue’s Clothes Kept the Focus on His Subjects
description: The talk show host made a career of exposing polarizing topics while dressed in a relatively neutral wardrobe.
content: The hoary tabloid axiom “if it bleeds, it leads” played no small part in the decades-long career of Phil Donahue, the pioneering host of “The Phil Donahue Show,” who died on Sunday at 88. Mr. Donahue spent three decades exposing subjects difficult for many Americans to confront — homosexuality, atheism, civil rights, consumer protection and abortion among them — to the disinfectant light of daytime TV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Benjamin Mullin
title: Can Harris Keep the Peace Among Progressives and C.E.O.s?
description: The vice president garnered public endorsements from progressives at the Democratic National Convention, but she must also keep corporate supporters on board.
content: Democrats rallied around Vice President Kamala Harris on the first night of their national convention, as the party seeks to hold together a coalition of progressives, labor leaders and big corporate donors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: 5 Takeaways from the ‘Love Island U.S.A.’ Season 6 Reunion
description: After a chaotic and fun season, even more drama unfolded on social media in the weeks that followed. This Peacock special broke everything down.
content: This summer’s season of “Love Island U.S.A.” has been the most popular of the franchise so far. And, if it feels like everyone is talking about it, it’s because they probably are — during the second week of July, this show was the most watched streaming original series in the U.S., according to Luminate, an entertainment data tracking service. That means it outranked “The Bear.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: 5 Breakouts From Classical Music’s Most Prestigious Festival
description: The Salzburg Festival is synonymous with excellence and fame. But it’s also a place where artists on the cusp of stardom can shine.
content: The Salzburg Festival has, since its founding more than 100 years ago, been known as a gathering place for the world’s finest musicians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: ‘A Battleground in an Intergenerational Conflict’: The Week 9 Winner of Our Summer Reading Contest
description: In a short video, Vanessa Chen, 16, muses about the meaning of the current “sock war” between millennials and Gen Z.
content: Though our 15th annual Summer Reading Contest is now over for the year, we’re still crowning finalists, and this week, for the second time this summer, a video has taken our top spot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Houman Barekat
title: Want to See a Play About Gwyneth Paltrow’s Ski Trial? How About 2?
description: Multiple shows at the Edinburgh Fringe make camp fun out of the 2023 civil action that spurred a thousand memes — and one of them is a triumph.
content: Terry Sanderson, a retired optometrist, was unsuccessful when he sued the actress turned wellness entrepreneur Gwyneth Paltrow over a collision on a Utah ski slope. Though he claimed that she had crashed into him, a jury determined it was actually his fault. The live-streamed 2023 civil case was an unseemly but strangely fascinating spectacle featuring two equally dislikable archetypes: the vexatious litigant and the preening, out-of-touch celebrity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Carl Hulse
title: In Chicago, Democrats Are Newly Hopeful They Can Win the Fight for Congress
description: As they gather to formally nominate Vice President Kamala Harris, top Democrats say their candidates — who they feared would be dragged to defeat by President Biden — now have the wind at their backs.
content: When Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York and the majority leader, and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, huddled for a few moments between events in a congested back hallway in a hotel on the sidelines of the Democratic National Convention, they could barely contain their ebullience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg
title: The Obamas and Awkward Dating Stories: Takeaways From the Democratic Convention
description: On Day 2, Barack and Michelle Obama electrified the crowd, while Doug Emhoff, husband of Vice President Kamala Harris, shared stories of their early romance.
content: Democrats turned to their most charismatic leaders and shifted toward the future on Tuesday, as former President Barack Obama and Michelle Obama, the former first lady, made the case that their party’s ticket represented the best of American values.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion
title: ‘He Didn’t So Much Pass the Torch as Set It Ablaze’: The Best and Worst Moments From Night 1 of the Convention
description: What our columnists and contributors thought of speeches from Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Hillary Clinton and Joe Biden on the event’s first night.
content: Welcome to Opinion’s commentary for Night 1 of the Democratic National Convention. In this special feature, Times Opinion writers rate the evening on a scale of 0 to 10: 0 means the night was a disaster for Kamala Harris; 10 means it could lead to a big polling bump. Here’s what our columnists and contributors thought of the event, which included speeches by Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Hillary Clinton, Raphael Warnock and Joe Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: At SEA, the Jungsik Team Focuses on Southeast Asian Cuisine
description: Jungsik Yim and his executive chef, Jun Hee Park, serve Thai pork links with sticky rice, and fried chicken with som tum and zabb spices.
content: Do not think crabmeat and cod because the name means Southeast Asia. You’ll find Thai pork links with sticky rice, fried chicken with som tum and zabb spices, razor clams with morning glory, and scrumptious St. Louis ribs, Frenched so they’re easily grasped. Jungsik Yim, whose 13-year old Jungsik, in TriBeCa, takes a creative approach to his native Korean food and has pushed the boundaries further here, based on his travels. The executive chef, Jun Hee Park, also comes from Jungsik. Raw wood and green accents define the space. Next year, SEA Lab, with an open kitchen and a 15-seat counter, will open downstairs for special dinners. (Opens Wednesday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Maria Branyas Morera, World’s Oldest Person, Dies at 117
description: Ms. Branyas, who cultivated a following on social media as “Super Catalan Grandma,” died peacefully in her sleep, her family said.
content: Maria Branyas Morera, an American-born Spanish woman believed to be the oldest person in the world, has died, according to her family. She was 117.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: A Desperate Kennedy Campaign, and the Mystery of 110,000 Signatures
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s presidential team relied on a super PAC for the signatures needed to get on the ballot in Arizona, according to people with knowledge of the operation.
content: On Friday, a longtime friend of Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the independent candidate for president, delivered boxes carrying 110,000 signatures to election officials in Arizona, to secure ballot access in a critical battleground state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Lauren Hirsch
title: Paramount Draws a New Bid, Complicating Deal With Skydance
description: The offer by Edgar Bronfman Jr., the former head of Warner Music Group, comes days before a crucial deadline in the scramble to acquire control of Paramount.
content: Edgar Bronfman Jr., the former chief executive of Warner Music Group and the heir to the Seagram fortune, submitted a bid on Monday to gain control of Paramount, the media conglomerate that owns CBS, MTV and the movie studio behind such hits as “The Godfather” and “Mission: Impossible,” according to two people familiar with the offer who were not authorized to speak publicly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: 25 Years Ago, a Gay Student Sought Support. His School Turned to Tim Walz.
description: One student’s turbulent coming-out journey in the 1990s put Mr. Walz, then a football coach, at the center of gay rights in a Minnesota high school.
content: Follow the latest news on the Democratic National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austyn Gaffney
title: New York City’s Trees Work Hard. Still, They Could Use a Little Help.
description: A chemical reaction involving emissions from cars and buildings can negate their environmental benefits. New research shows what big cities can do about it.
content: Oak trees with leaves like outstretched hands and thick, stately trunks reduce the effects of extreme heat around New York City’s five boroughs by shading sidewalks and sucking up planet-warming carbon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Clinton Rallies Democrats Behind Harris: ‘This Is When We Break Through’
description: Eight years after failing to smash the “highest and hardest glass ceiling” in politics, Hillary Clinton urged her party to make Kamala Harris the nation’s first female president.
content: The last time Hillary Clinton appeared in person before a Democratic National Convention, the year was 2016, the city was Philadelphia and Mrs. Clinton was accepting her party’s nomination to run for president in what her audience thought would be a shoo-in of a race against Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: New Yorkers Who Live Next to a Stadium Say They Can’t Take It Anymore
description: Noise complaints by residents of Forest Hills Gardens, an enclave in Queens that hugs Forest Hills Stadium, have led to legal wrangling and petitions.
content: Today we’ll look at Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, where concerts have taken the place of the U.S. Open, to the dismay of some residents. We’ll also get details on a new lawsuit that seeks to keep Robert F. Kennedy Jr. off the November ballot in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman and Hari Kumar
title: Global Trade Needs a China Alternative. India Needs Better Ports.
description: Efforts to build new ports and expand existing docks could determine whether India emerges as a legitimate option for global factory production.
content: The Rishiri Galaxy, a Panamian-flagged tanker one and a half times the length of a football field, sat tethered to the dock on a muggy day at the Jawaharlal Nehru Port on the west coast of India. Freshly arrived from the Persian Gulf, it bore industrial chemicals — raw materials for Indian factories that make pharmaceuticals, auto parts, cosmetics, construction materials and scores of other modern concoctions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Can Democrats Make the Case to Climate Voters?
description: In another year of record-breaking temperatures, Democrats are faced with the challenge of making climate change resonate with voters.
content: It was another summer weekend in America, complete with wildfires in California, flash floods in Connecticut and violent storms in Tennessee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Zelensky Says Push Into Russia Shows the West’s Red Lines Are ‘Naïve’
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine seized on the incursion’s success to press allies to lift a longtime restriction: the use of Western-supplied long-range weapons against Russia.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky has said that Ukraine’s surprise offensive into western Russia, which entered its third week on Tuesday, shows the West that its fears about the ramifications of attacks on Russian territory are unfounded and should be abandoned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Ocasio-Cortez, Once an Outsider, Takes Center Stage at Convention
description: In a prime-time speech, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez gave a forceful endorsement of Kamala Harris.
content: Four years ago, Democrats allotted Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York a scant 90 seconds to speak at their convention. She used it to symbolically nominate Senator Bernie Sanders for president and never mentioned Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Why Is My C-Section Scar Painful, Itchy and Sometimes Smelly?
description: The symptoms can occur months or even years after the surgery.
content: Q: I had a C-section about a year ago, but my scar still sometimes hurts, itches and even smells. What’s going on?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Tropical Depression Jongdari Nears South Korea, Bringing Threat of Flooding
description: The storm has caused flight cancellations in the country’s south. It is forecast to skirt the west coast before making landfall on Wednesday near Seoul.
content: Tropical Depression Jongdari moved toward South Korea on Tuesday, threatening to buffet the country with heavy rain and strong winds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing Grounds 777-9 Test Planes in Latest Setback
description: The airplane manufacturer said it had discovered problems with a key part of the 777-9, a large plane designed for long flights that had already been delayed by years.
content: Boeing said on Tuesday that it had paused test flights of the 777-9, a large plane whose development had already been delayed by years, after discovering problems with a key part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden Approved Secret Nuclear Strategy Refocusing on Chinese Threat
description: In a classified document approved in March, the president ordered U.S. forces to prepare for possible coordinated nuclear confrontations with Russia, China and North Korea.
content: President Biden approved in March a highly classified nuclear strategic plan for the United States that, for the first time, reorients America’s deterrent strategy to focus on China’s rapid expansion in its nuclear arsenal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Ukrainian Lawmakers Pass Bill Aiming to Ban Russian-Aligned Church
description: The measure, which awaits President Volodymyr Zelensky’s signature, would further a long, post-Soviet split between two of the world’s largest Orthodox communities.
content: Ukraine’s Parliament passed a bill on Tuesday creating a legal path to ban a Russian-aligned branch of the Orthodox church, furthering a long, post-Soviet split between two of the world’s largest Orthodox communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Silver
title: I Have Been Studying Poker for Years. Kamala Harris Isn’t Bluffing.
description: So far in the 2024 election, the party known for aversion to risk has been making better risk-management decisions.
content: In recent years, for a new book, I have spent time in a community of like-minded thinkers who take calculated risks for a living. These people, from poker players to venture capitalists — I call them the River, and they are from Silicon Valley, Wall Street, sports betting, crypto — make decisions based not on what they know at the moment but on expected value. For them, when it is time to make a decision, the question is: Do the risks outweigh the rewards?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘It Was Scary, the Good Kind’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: I left a Christian cult. Tried Hinge, and the best conversation I had with a man was about Taco Bell. I switched my preference (I came out as a lesbian at 14, and was now coming back out at 27). Quickly, I fell for Jillian. It was scary, the good kind. Sobering, like we had known each other before. Kind, like you just want to rest in each other’s presence. We’ve lost parents, jobs, community; faced life-threatening illnesses. Of course it’s hard. But it’s better together. “Damn,” I often tell Jillian, “life is hard; but this, this is easy.” — Jordan Kates
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: Judge Blocks F.T.C.’s Noncompete Rule
description: The Federal Trade Commission was deemed to lack the authority to bar companies from restricting their employees’ ability to go to work for rivals.
content: A federal judge on Tuesday upheld a challenge to the Federal Trade Commission’s ban on noncompete agreements, blocking it from taking effect in September as scheduled.
source.name: The New York Times

title: For These Top Artists, Holograms Offer a New Dimension

Unrecognized out of drag, Jules decides to entrap and humiliate his attacker, and if you think you know where this is going, you’re in for a surprise. Rather than rehashing the tired, simplistic tropes of the revenge thriller, the writing and directing duo Sam H. Freeman and Ng Choon Ping explore the emotional complexities of the trap Jules must set — and in doing so, pose compelling questions about Jules’s own sense of self-worth. Stewart-Jarrett is marvelously understated, carefully choosing when to let his character’s carefully cultivated persona slip, while McKay is chillingly convincing in his tricky characterization of a closeted, self-loathing gay man.

author: By Linda Kinstler
title: The Bitter Fight Over the Meaning of ‘Genocide’
description: Debates over how to describe conflicts in Gaza, Myanmar and elsewhere are channeling a controversy as old as the word itself.
content: On Feb. 26, 2007, Smail Čekić stormed out of the Peace Palace, the seat of the International Court of Justice, carrying the decision the judges had just handed down. The case that concluded that day, Bosnia v. Serbia, was to determine whether Serbia had violated the Genocide Convention during the Bosnian War, when Bosnian Serb forces killed an estimated 100,000 civilians. Čekić, then the director of Sarajevo University’s Institute for Research of Crimes Against Humanity and International Law and a Bosnian victim of the war, had hoped the court, which is based in The Hague, would punish his compatriots’ deaths and acknowledge them as victims of genocide. Instead, the court declined to classify a vast majority of the Bosnian deaths as genocidal. For Čekić and other survivors, the ruling was a betrayal: They felt that the court had refused to recognize the true nature of the violence. Newspapers reported that Serbia had been found not guilty of genocide; a celebration was planned at the Serbian Embassy. Standing outside the I.C.J., the top court of the United Nations, Čekić tore the text of the judgment to pieces.

content: Myron E. Ullman III, the unassuming retail executive who gave Macy’s a strategic makeover, revitalized J.C. Penney during two stints as chief executive, and held key positions at Starbucks and the French conglomerate LVMH, died on Aug. 6 in Grand Junction, Colo. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Biden Went on Late. Democrats Offered a Culprit: ‘Raucous Applause.’
description: The official explanation for Monday’s elongated convention telecast prompted one CNN pundit to compliment the “amazing spin.”
content: A performance by James Taylor? Cut. Tribute video? Shelved. President Biden’s speech? Started late and ended in the wee hours of the East Coast morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Behind the Obama-Harris Friendship: A Key Endorsement and a Kindred Spirit
description: Kamala Harris’s decision to support Barack Obama in a 2008 primary race dominated by Hillary Clinton was a political risk. It paid off, and the former president never forgot it.
content: On New Year’s Eve in 2007, Kamala Harris, then the district attorney of San Francisco, prepared to spend the holiday more than a thousand miles away from her native California. She had flown to Iowa for the first time, touching down in Des Moines during one of the wettest winters on record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: In a Speech Meant to Focus on Crime, Trump Meanders Off Script
description: He veered toward the economy. He popped into foreign policy. He repeated his false claims of a stolen election. And he mocked his opponent, Kamala Harris.
content: On just the second day of a weeklong tour that his campaign said would focus on specific policy issues, former President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday went to a sheriff’s office in Michigan and frequently deviated from what was billed as a speech on crime and public safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel Says It Recovered Bodies of 6 Hostages in Gaza
description: The bodies were retrieved in an overnight operation in southern Gaza, the Israeli military said. Five of the hostages were already known to have died in captivity.
content: Israeli forces recovered the bodies of six Israeli hostages from southern Gaza in an overnight operation, the Israeli military said on Tuesday, highlighting the plight of the scores of captives remaining in the Palestinian enclave. Five of the six were previously known to have lost their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

title: News Emmys Defend Nomination of Palestinian Journalist
description: A nonprofit had argued that a video from Gaza should be disqualified, accusing the reporter of having a history of “spreading antisemitism and condoning violence.”
content: The group behind the News and Documentary Emmy Awards defended its nomination of a video report from Gaza on Tuesday after the journalist who filmed it was criticized for her connection to a group the United States considers a terrorist organization.

title: Alaska Airlines’ Acquisition of Hawaiian Clears Key Antitrust Review
description: The airlines said the Justice Department had declined to challenge the merger in court.

author: By Max Keller
title: This Is My Voice One Year on T
description: A transgender music critic explores the change in their singing voice after taking testosterone.
content: When I started taking testosterone last year, I was eager for the effects it would have on my speaking voice. I imagined talking in a voice that was low, smooth, soothing. But my high singing voice felt somehow sacrosanct. I didn’t really want it to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Steve Kerr Cheers on Harris and Walz, a Fellow Coach
description: The Golden State Warriors coach, well known for his liberal views, wove plenty of sports references into his paean to the Democratic ticket. He also teased Tim Walz a bit.
content: Steve Kerr, the coach of the Golden State Warriors, praised Vice President Kamala Harris onstage on Monday night and urged Americans to come together to reject former President Donald J. Trump as if they were one united basketball team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Joseph
title: A Berry Pudding That Tastes Like Danish Summertime
description: Rødgrød med fløde takes Mette Hay, a co-founder of the home goods company Hay, back to her grandparents’ garden.
content: In Denmark, rødgrød med fløde, a fruity, cream-topped pudding, is a traditional summer treat. But when the Danish designer Mette Hay was growing up in the town of Herning, 170 miles west of Copenhagen, she enjoyed the dessert year-round. It was such a staple, in fact, that she refers to her grandmother’s version — made by simmering red and black currants, blackberries, raspberries, strawberries and rhubarb with a little sugar and vanilla — as “the taste of my childhood.” Her grandmother, she says, made everything from scratch, using berries she and Hay’s grandfather would pick from their garden. “And they always had enough to freeze portions to last them through the winter.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Jenny Gross
title: Europe Slashes Tariffs for Tesla Vehicles Made in China
description: The European Commission plans to lower a proposed duty on the U.S. automaker’s electric vehicles imported from China to 9 percent, less than that of its Chinese peers.
content: The European Union is proposing to charge Tesla an additional tariff of 9 percent on its vehicles imported from China while other automakers face rates as high as 36.3 percent, as part of efforts to protect European producers from unfair competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Finbarr O'Reilly
title: War Is Draining Ukraine’s Male-Dominated Work Force. Enter the Women.
description: More and more women are replacing men mobilized in the army. But there are not enough of them to make up for the labor shortage affecting the economy.
content: On a recent morning in eastern Ukraine, Karina Yatsina, a mine worker, was busy operating a conveyor belt in a dim, 1,200-foot-deep tunnel. Lights flickered at the end of the shaft, illuminating miners carving out the coal seams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: A Waterspout Was Seen When a Luxury Yacht Sank. What Is It?
description: Witnesses reported seeing the tornado-like phenomenon hit the Bayesian, a sailing yacht that sank off the coast of Sicily on Monday.
content: What caused the sinking on Monday of a sailing yacht carrying the British billionaire Mike Lynch and 21 other people off the coast of Sicily is still unknown. But some attention has focused on observations by witnesses, who described seeing a small tornado-like column known as a waterspout forming over the water during an abrupt and violent storm as the vessel sank.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Mississippi’s Freedom Trail Will Now Extend All the Way to New Jersey
description: As Democrats rally in Chicago around Kamala Harris, civil rights veterans will mark the 60th anniversary of history-changing testimony at a past convention in Atlantic City, N.J.
content: Euvester Simpson was barely 18 in August 1964 when she boarded a bus in Mississippi bound for the Democratic National Convention in New Jersey.

title: Scientists Seeking Life on Mars Heard a Signal That Hinted at the Future
description: In 1924, a radio receiver built for the battlefields of World War I tested the idea that humans were not alone in the solar system, heralding a century of searches for extraterrestrial life.
content: At sunset on a late summer weekend in 1924, crowds flocked to curbside telescopes to behold the advanced alien civilization they believed to be present on the surface of Mars.

author: By Maggie Astor and Caroline Gutman
title: How Two Democrats Jumped Into Politics and Ended Up as Delegates
description: Janet Diaz and Tameko Patterson barely knew each other before this year, but both had long journeys into the political arena. Now they are rooming together and representing their party in Chicago.
content: Ten years ago, Janet Diaz and Tameko Patterson were not particularly engaged in politics. This week, they are rooming together in Chicago as delegates to the Democratic National Convention: some of the most powerful yet little-known people in the party.

title: U.S. Sanctions Former Haitian President for Drug Trafficking
description: The Treasury Department said former President Michel Martelly’s actions have contributed significantly to the unraveling of security in the country.
content: The United States imposed sanctions against former President Michel Martelly of Haiti for drug trafficking and money laundering, according to a U.S. Treasury Department statement released Tuesday, accusing him of contributing to the destabilization and unrest afflicting the Caribbean nation.
